user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarCreate_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarCreate_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 options)
{
    int32                              final_status;
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    final_status = OS_SUCCESS;
    impl         = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    /*
    ** create the underlying mutex
    */
    status = pthread_mutex_init(&impl->mut, NULL);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error: CondVar mutex could not be created. ID = %lu: %s\n",
                 OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(status));
        final_status = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
        ** create the condvar
        */
        status = pthread_cond_init(&impl->cv, NULL);
        if (status != 0)
        {
            pthread_mutex_destroy(&impl->mut);

            OS_DEBUG("Error: CondVar could not be created. ID = %lu: %s\n",
                     OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(status));
            final_status = OS_ERROR;
        }
    }

    return final_status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_CondVarCreate_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
static inline unsigned long OS_ObjectIdToInteger(osal_id_t object_id)
{
#ifdef OSAL_OMIT_DEPRECATED
    return object_id.v;
#else
    return object_id;
#endif
}
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_DEBUG("Error: CondVar could not be created. ID = %lu: %s\n",
                     OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(status));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The code fragment only reads the token parameter (passed to OS_ObjectIdFromToken which returns token->obj_id) and does not modify the pointer or the pointee. All functions/macros involved take a const pointer or otherwise do not alter the parameter, so Rule 17.8 is not violated.
